Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They encounter a situation where a friend is being treated unfairly and feel a stronger responsibility to intervene or speak up.
Story: I was looking forward to this week—finally, both of us had free evenings, and we could plan a proper date. He’d been hinting at a new restaurant, and I could already imagine us laughing over dinner, just the two of us. But then, today, I saw our friend Priya being blamed for something she didn’t do at work. The injustice stung, and I felt a deep urge to stand by her, to speak up, just as my parents taught me—dharma above all, always do what’s right. But if I get involved, it might take up my evenings, and I know he’s been waiting for this time together. I can almost hear his disappointment if I cancel, and I want to be there for him, to nurture our relationship. Yet, my conscience tugs at me, reminding me of my duty to fairness and truth. My heart aches, caught between being the girlfriend he needs and the person my faith expects me to be.
